If the characters detect them, the duergar explain their purpose and offer to escort them to Valtagar.

Characters who succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check can identify the bare footprints as belonging to two separate bipedal creatures, both very large and deformed. These tracks crisscross the cave with enough frequency to imply that their makers dwell nearby. A successful check also reveals three sets of dwarf-sized boot prints, allowing the tracker to follow the prints straight to the {@condition invisible} duergar.

entries.name: 4b. Something Wicked
entries: Two {@creature fomorian||fomorians} dumped here by Halaster rest at the back of this 20-foot-high cave. These hideously misshapen giants are new to Undermountain and believe the mines are haunted by dwarven ghosts. In actuality, they have been rattled by the sounds of {@condition invisible} duergar moving about and talking to one another.
The fomorians are tired of licking blood and slime off rocks to fill their bellies, prompting them to attack smaller creatures on sight.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: At the back of the fomorians' cave are two sacks made of gas spore hide. One sack contains 2,100 cp, 1,590 sp, 480 gp, and the broken pieces of a wooden rocking chair. The other contains thirteen misshapen chunks of yellow quartz (50 gp each) and a rusty iron rowboat anchor that weighs 30 pounds.

entries.name: 4c. Dead-End Loop
entries: This mine tunnel loops back on itself. The floor is littered with slime-covered rocks, which the fomorians have been licking for nourishment.

entries.name: 4d. Dead-End Fork
entries: This tunnel terminates in two dead ends, both heaped with piles of rubble. The west fork once connected with a tunnel to the south, but the roof caved in. The collapse looks recent—within the past month or so.
{@b Dust and Debris}. Dust falls from cracks in the 15-foot-high ceiling, covering a rubble-strewn floor.
{@b Noise}. A tunnel to the south (leading to {@area areas 16|a56|x} and {@area 18|a67}) echoes with the sounds of hammers and picks striking stone.

entries.name: 6. Duergar Outpost
entries: Areas {@area 6a|a39} through {@area 6c|a3b} have 10-foot-high ceilings. Streaks of blood cover their tiled floors and walls.

The duergar stationed in these areas have orders to escort visitors to {@creature Valtagar Steelshadow|WDMM} in {@area area 15|a4f|x}. If combat erupts in one room, the occupants of the other two rooms join the fight. The {@creature duergar} in areas {@area 17a|a5f} and {@area 17b|a60} also hear the commotion and investigate, moving 50 feet per round. Valtagar and others in nearby areas might also hear the activity, but they remain where they are.

entries.name: 6a. North Watch Post
entries: Two female {@creature duergar} named Kavalra and Nisha guard this chamber.

entries.name: 6b. South Watch Post
entries: Four {@creature duergar}, two males named Duldor and Grimdor and two females named Marna and Ukzorra, maintain a guard station here.

entries.name: 6c. Command Post
entries: The northern half of the room contains a stone desk and a high-backed chair—furnishings brought here from area 16d. Seated behind the desk is Valtagar's captain of the guard, Rojkarn Ironhead, a {@creature duergar} with 40 hit points. He wears a tall helm bristling with spikes and fitted with a scowling iron mask. He is flanked by two female {@creature duergar} bodyguards named Brona and Ubrix.

Rojkarn is cruel, cantankerous, and blindly loyal to {@creature Valtagar Steelshadow|WDMM}. It pains him to see Valtagar submit to the evil planetar's will. Rojkarn spends much of his waking hours complaining about how the planetar is nothing but a mad tyrant and ranting about how duergar are meant to rule, not be ruled. With each new tirade, Brona and Ubrix roll their eyes in exasperation.

entries.name: 7. Cleric's End
entries: This tunnel slopes up toward the northeast, intersecting multiple rubble-strewn passages along the way. A mine track runs the length of the passageway.

When the characters first arrive, a silent, spectral scene plays out before them: a middle-aged human cleric wildly swings her {@item mace of smiting} at an unseen foe. The cleric wears a blood-streaked breastplate emblazoned with a white right-handed gauntlet (the symbol of Torm). Suddenly, as she pulls her mace back for another swing, her head separates from her shoulders, sliced off by an invisible blade. Then the image fades.

entries.name: 8. Mining Equipment
entries: This 10-foot-high room contains rusty helmets, picks, hammers, and pitons on stone shelves along the walls.

entries.name: 9. Miners' Quarters
entries: This 10-foot-high room is constructed of interlocking, blood-streaked stone tiles. Rectangular stone slabs lie in neat rows against the east and west walls. These slabs once served as beds for dwarf miners, but they have not been used in centuries.
A thick layer of dust covers everything.

entries.name: 10. Common Areas
entries: Most of the ceilings in this area are 10 feet high. Blood-smeared tiles cover the floors and walls throughout.

entries.name: 10a. Dining Hall
entries: This room has a vaulted ceiling, rising 15 feet high. The guards in {@area area 10b|a42|x} notice any light or noise here and quickly investigate. The room has the following features:
{@b Table and Benches}. A 25-foot-long stone dining table is in the middle of the room, flanked by two equally long stone benches.
{@b Hutch}. A stone hutch against the west wall contains assorted iron plates and flatware.

entries.name: 10b. Den
entries: This room is largely empty, having been stripped of furniture. Two male {@creature duergar} guards named Malgorn and Zelk stand watch here. They have orders to escort visitors to {@creature Valtagar Steelshadow|WDMM} in {@area area 15|a4f|x}.

Malgorn is one card away from owning a complete deck of Three-Dragon Ante cards made of thin-pressed gold. He has begun obsessing over the missing card ("The Thief") and complains about it incessantly. He has found the other cards scattered throughout the Terminus Level and is storing them in a pouch tied to his belt. He's not optimistic about finding the last card, though. Sick of hearing about the situation, Zelk adds to Malgorn's misery by repeatedly asking him if he has searched in places he knows Malgorn has already thoroughly checked.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Each of the sixty-nine gold cards in Malgorn's incomplete deck is worth 10 gp, but the set is worth 2,500 gp once the deck contains all seventy cards. The characters can find the missing card in {@area area 23c|a83|x}.

entries.name: 11. Kitchen and Pantry
entries: Food is stored and prepared here. The blood that leaks from the walls and floors makes little of it appetizing.

entries.name: 11a. Kitchen

entries: {@b Fireplace}. This 15-foot-high room is warm and smells of cheap spices. A large fireplace dominates the west wall. A bed of hot coals fills the hearth with smoke and orange light. Suspended above the coals is a covered iron cauldron.
{@b Duergar Cook}. An old, hunchbacked duergar wearing what amounts to a dusty gray sack stirs the cauldron with an iron spoon. He is without armor or weapons.
{@b Preparation Area}. Short stone tables in the middle of the kitchen are used for food preparation. Utensils hang from hooks above them.
{@b Sink}. A stone faucet and handle jut from the south wall, just above a semicircular basin enclosed by a 2-foot-high retaining wall.

The cook, Lorga, prepares bland mushroom stew. Despite his blinding cataracts, he knows his way around the kitchen and the adjoining pantry. If he hears one or more characters enter, he shouts in Dwarvish, "The stew will be ready when it's ready! Get out, lest ye taste none of it!" If they don't leave at once, he says, "My eyes are clouded, but my ears and nose work fine. Test not my resolve!"

A {@spell lesser restoration} spell or similar magic restores Lorga's sight. He offers no thanks to whoever rids him of the disability. As dour and pessimistic as any other duergar, he quickly finds something else to complain about.

Lorga poses no threat (0 XP). He merely wishes to die serving Valtagar, whom he has known since the prince was a child. Lorga isn't holding out hope that he'll ever hear the belching forges of Gracklstugh again, but it infuriates him that Valtagar—a duergar prince—must kowtow to the "mad giant" {@creature Fazrian|WDMM}. Lorga suggests that the characters locate Valtagar and forge an alliance with him before they all fall to the giant's sword.

Once the hot coals are doused or swept from the fireplace, the chimney can be climbed easily. After 90 feet, it breaks into a damp, soot-stained natural cave roughly 50 feet square. The cave contains nothing of interest.

Turning the handle on the faucet opens a valve that allows fresh, cold water from an underground stream to pour into the basin and mix with the blood pooling there (see "{@area Regional Effects|a21|x}"). A stone plug covers the drainpipe in the bottom of the basin.

entries.name: 11b. Pantry
entries: Fifty gray sacks rest atop stone shelves carved into the walls of this 10-foot-high room. The sacks contain edible fungi and dried moss.

entries.name: 12. Miners' Potty
entries: Thin, crumbling brick walls divide the northern half of this 10-foot-high room into three stalls, each one tucked behind a rusty chain-link curtain that hangs limply from the ceiling. Cut into the floor of each stall is a circular hole that leads to a cesspit.

entries.name: 13. Grand Vestibule

entries: {@b Blood}. Blood leaks down the walls and across the decor of this once grand hall.

{@b Pillars}. Four stone pillars buttress the 30-foot-high vaulted ceiling. The middle third of each pillar is carved to look like a scowling dwarf with bulging muscles that supports the column's upper third on its broad shoulders. Blue sapphires glitter in the dwarves' eyes.

{@b Double Door}. The doors in the east wall stand 18 feet high, a carving of a mighty waterfall spanning their surfaces. Mithral inlays make the carved falls look like they are running with molten metal.
{@b Curtain}. A 40-foot-long, 20-foot-high curtain of black dragon scales hangs from an iron rod bolted to the west wall. (The scales have become brittle with age and are not valuable.)
{@b Hanging Horn}. Suspended from the ceiling by iron chains is a 20-foot-long iron horn with etched Dwarvish runes coiling around it.

The giant horn weighs 2 tons. It dangles 20 feet above the floor on three thick, 5-foot-long iron chains. The Melairkyn dwarves forged the horn and placed it here to guard the treasure in this hall (see "Treasure" below). A {@spell detect magic} spell or similar magic reveals an aura of conjuration magic around the horn. A character who understands Dwarvish can translate the horn's runes, not all of which are visible from the floor. The runes visible from the floor read, "If you blind us." A character must fly up to the horn or climb above it to read the message in its entirety, which is "If you blind us, shall we not revenge?"

Removing one or more gemstones from the pillars causes the horn to magically emit a somber tone. As the horn sounds, the spirits of thirteen dwarf warriors appear in unoccupied spaces throughout the hall and attack all other creatures in the area. These unaligned spirits use the {@creature champion|VGM} statistics (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}), except that they wield greataxes instead of greatswords. They understand Dwarvish but can't speak, and they can't leave the hall. They disappear after 1 hour or when they drop to 0 hit points. Once the horn has sounded, it can't sound again until 7 days have passed. If no gemstones remain in the pillars when this time elapses, the horn becomes nonmagical and can no longer summon dwarven spirits. Removing the instrument from the hall also renders it nonmagical.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Eight blue star sapphires (1,000 gp each) are embedded in the eyes of the dwarf carvings—two gemstones per pillar. Each gem is set 18 feet above the floor and can be pried out with a dagger or similar tool.

entries.name: 14. Shrine of Laduguer
entries: As a gesture of goodwill toward its new duergar allies, {@creature Fazrian|WDMM} had this waiting chamber converted into a shrine of Laduguer, the duergar god of labor and slavery. Presiding over the shrine are two {@creature Arcanaloth||arcanaloths} named Aximus and Exekarus. These fiends use {@spell alter self} spells to appear as duergar priests. Valtagar and the duergar under his command avoid the shrine, finding the yugoloths' presence insulting and their motives suspicious.

The room has a flat, 10-foot-high ceiling. Although blood often flows from gaps between the room's wall tiles (see "{@area Regional Effects|a21|x}"), Aximus and Exekarus regularly use {@spell prestidigitation} cantrips to clean it away. The room's other contents are as follows:
{@b Haze}. A thin, smoky haze fills the room. (The haze doesn't obscure the room's other features.)

{@b Braziers}. Alcoves in the north wall contain two braziers fashioned from melted-down iron armor and weapons. Each is alight with burning coals that shed bright light in a 10-foot radius and dim light for an additional 10 feet.

{@b Altar and Shield}. Between the alcoves, an iron altar traced with silver and shaped like a giant anvil rests beneath a round, 10-foot-diameter iron shield mounted on the north wall. The shield bears the symbol of a broken arrow with a jagged arrowhead. Standing before the altar are a pair of duergar (Aximus and Exekarus) in drab robes.

To prepare for their roles, the arcanaloths learned everything they could about Laduguer's principles of conduct. To their surprise, Aximus and Exekarus found these principles compelling. Some of the arcanaloths' favorite maxims include:

items: "No matter how much wealth and power you have, it's never enough."
"The fight never ends. Take what you deserve and destroy all who stand in your way."
"Let no emotion rule you. Abandon joy, love, pride, anger, and ambition, for they are signs of weakness. Know your role and perform it to the best of your ability."

entries: Laduguer's dogma guides Aximus and Exekarus as much as it does any duergar, and the yugoloths try to impose these principles on all who claim to serve {@creature Fazrian|WDMM}. If the characters haven't encountered {@creature Fazrian|WDMM}, Aximus and Exekarus insist on taking them to meet the planetar, whom they admire. Those who refuse to accompany the arcanaloths are left behind as Aximus and Exekarus proceed to {@area area 23b|a7f|x} to inform {@creature Fazrian|WDMM} that visitors have arrived. Obedience to {@creature Fazrian|WDMM} is all that matters to Aximus and Exekarus—at least until someone convinces the arcanaloths to switch allegiances.

The arcanaloths' attitude toward the characters is indifferent at the start, though the fiends quickly turn hostile if attacked. The arcanaloths' attitude changes to friendly if the characters appeal to their love of magic by giving them a single very rare magic item, multiple rare magic items, or a spellbook containing at least one spell of 6th level or higher. Aximus and Exekarus make their love of all things magical known to anyone that seeks their assistance. If their attitude toward the characters is changed in this way, the arcanaloths repay the party's kindness any way they can—short of placing themselves in harm's way. Their helpfulness doesn't last long, however. After 24 hours, the arcanaloths' attitude toward the party becomes indifferent once more, and further bribes are needed to regain their assistance.

The large iron shield hanging on the wall weighs 750 pounds and bears the broken arrow symbol of Laduguer. Any duergar recognizes the symbol right away, while non-duergar recognize it with a successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check. Any humanoid that touches the shield becomes cursed with the flaw: "I take no joy or pleasure in anything." This flaw supersedes any opposing flaw. Casting a {@spell remove curse} spell or similar magic on the creature ends the curse on it.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Aximus and Exekarus hide their spellbooks in the folds of their robes. Each book contains all the spells the arcanaloths have prepared, plus {@spell eyebite}, {@spell forcecage}, and {@spell incendiary cloud}.

entries.name: 15. Valtagar's Quarters
entries: The walls and floor of this 15-foot-high chamber are covered with interlocking stone tiles. The room contains the following:

{@b Valtagar}. When the characters first arrive, {@creature Valtagar Steelshadow|WDMM} (see below) is reading his spellbook—a bound stack of mithral plates. The book rests atop a stout, stone lectern in the middle of the room.
{@b Golem}. Standing in the south corner is an {@creature iron golem} that looks like a 10-foot-tall duergar. The golem understands Dwarvish and obeys Valtagar's commands.
{@b Masks}. Dozens of iron masks hang from hooks on the southeast wall (see "{@area Iron Masks|a54|x}" below).
{@b Other Furnishings}. Against the northwest wall stands a low double bed. In the middle of the room, a locked iron strongbox rests atop a low marble table flanked by two stone chairs.

entries.name: Valtagar Steelshadow
entries: Valtagar wears a black robe with a cowl that obscures his face. Suspicious and volatile, he is a duergar {@creature archmage}, with these changes:

items: Valtagar is lawful evil.
He has the {@spell Otiluke's resilient sphere} spell prepared instead of {@spell banishment}.

He has these racial traits: He speaks Common, Dwarvish, Infernal, Terran, Troglodyte, and Undercommon. His walking speed is 25 feet, and he has {@sense darkvision} out to 120 feet. He has advantage on saving throws against poison and resistance to poison damage. He gains the Enlarge and Invisibility action options described below.

entries.name: Enlarge (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: For 1 minute, Valtagar magically increases in size. While enlarged, Valtagar is Large, doubles his damage dice on Strength-based weapon attacks, and makes Strength checks and Strength saving throws with advantage. If Valtagar lacks the space to become Large, he attains the maximum size possible in the space available.

entries.name: Invisibility (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: Valtagar magically turns {@condition invisible} for up to 1 hour or until he attacks, he casts a spell, he uses his Enlarge, or his concentration is broken (as if concentrating on a spell). Any equipment he wears or carries is {@condition invisible} with him.

Archmages are exceedingly rare in duergar society, and Valtagar's gift for wizardry never sat well with the clans of Gracklstugh. He doesn't put himself in harm's way unless he has a clear tactical edge. If the characters threaten him after they gain entry to his quarters, he orders his golem to attack while he grabs his spellbook off the lectern, casts {@spell teleport}, and joins his wife in {@area area 18d|a6b|x}.

Valtagar has faced adventurers before and has a healthy fear of them. If the characters are willing to engage in civil discourse, he tries to hire them to slay {@creature Fazrian|WDMM}. The patience of his duergar followers is wearing thin, and he loses nothing by setting the adventurers loose against the planetar. In exchange, Valtagar guarantees safe passage through his domain whenever they need it and promises to tell them the location of a secret staircase that descends to the next level of Undermountain (see {@area area 19a|a7a|x}). To establish trust, he tells them about the secret vault hidden behind {@creature Fazrian|WDMM}'s throne (see {@area area 24|a85|x}) and shares what he knows about {@creature Fazrian|WDMM} and its allies:

items: A powerful cleric summoned a celestial being of immense power named {@creature Fazrian|WDMM}, then directed it to slay a host of monsters that once haunted the Deep Mines.

That act of slaughter corrupted {@creature Fazrian|WDMM}. After slaying many monsters, it decapitated the cleric and installed itself as lord of the Deep Mines. {@creature Fazrian|WDMM} rarely leaves its throne hall and keeps the cleric's headless corpse as a memento.

{@creature Fazrian|WDMM} takes advice from four yugoloths. These fiends arrived shortly after {@creature Fazrian|WDMM}'s madness took hold. Aximus and Exekarus can be found in the nearby shrine of Laduguer ({@area area 14|a4c|x}). Raxxus is at {@creature Fazrian|WDMM}'s side ({@area area 23b|a7f|x}). Valtagar says that Xindulus roams where it will, choosing not to reveal that the ultroloth guards the secret staircase down to the next level of Undermountain ({@area area 19a|a7a|x}).

entries.name: Iron Masks
entries: The iron masks are visors taken from the helmets of duergar warriors who followed Valtagar throughout his exile, only to fall in battle. Valtagar displays them not for sentimental reasons, but to reinforce his determination to return home.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The mithral spellbook on the lectern weighs 30 pounds. It contains all the spells Valtagar has prepared. Its cover is embossed with a broken arrow, the symbol of Laduguer.

The iron strongbox contains 600 pp. Minted in Gracklstugh, these coins bear the stern visage of Deepking Horgar Steelshadow V on one side, the mind flayer skull symbol of Deep Duerra (the duergar god of conquest and psionics) on the other, and a Dwarvish motto on the rim that translates as "As low as we can go."

entries.name: 16. Fire and Iron
entries: The duergar use the forges in {@area areas 16a|a57|x} and {@area 16b|a59} to mold iron into 10-pound bars, which are stored in area 16c. Area 16d is an old overseer's office that the duergar have turned into a barracks. A total of fifteen duergar work and sleep in these areas.
The floors and walls are covered with interlocking, blood-streaked stone tiles. The ceiling is 10 feet high throughout.

entries.name: 16a. Northern Smelter

entries: {@b Smoke and Heat}. Smoke fills this room, making the area lightly obscured. The temperature inside the room is a searing 120 degrees Fahrenheit.
{@b Forge}. Roaring flames fill a stone forge that protrudes from the north wall.
{@b Smiths}. Two sweaty, unarmored {@creature duergar} are working the forge, smelting iron. Both wear tinted goggles and thick gloves.
{@b Buckets}. Piled around the forge are buckets of iron ore.

The duergar are a male named Brok and a female named Fumira. Brok uses long-handled iron tongs to place chunks of iron ore in the forge. Once the iron melts, Fumira scoops out the molten iron with a long-handled ladle and pours it into two iron molds, which Brok clamps shut. They then take the clamped molds to {@area area 16c|a5a|x} to cool. Afterward, they return to the forge with two empty molds and repeat the process.

Without their armor, Brok and Fumira have AC 10. They keep their war picks and javelins close by, but fight only in self-defense. If they detect intruders, they stop working and grouchily offer to escort the new arrivals to Rojkarn Ironhead, the captain of the guard ({@area area 6c|a3b|x})—leading the party through areas {@area 16c|a5a}, {@area 6b|a3a}, and {@area 6a|a39}. The duergar have nothing much to say to visitors, preferring to let Rojkarn answer any questions they might have.
If a fight breaks out, the duergar in {@area areas 16b|a59|x} and 16d quickly join the battle. (The duergar in area {@area 16c|a5a} is deaf.)

The forge puts out tremendous heat thanks to a {@creature fire elemental} magically trapped inside it. Runes carved on the inside walls of the forge prevent the elemental from escaping or harming anyone outside the forge. Destroying the forge releases the elemental, whereupon it attacks everyone in sight. The forge has AC 17, 80 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage.

entries.name: 16b. Southern Smelter
entries: This room is identical to {@area area 16a|a57|x} except that the forge protrudes from the south wall, and the two unarmored {@creature duergar} working here are a pair of females named Krinxa and Wolthra.

entries.name: 16c. Iron Stockpile

entries: {@b Duergar}. In the north half of the room, an elderly male {@creature duergar} carrying an iron cane and an ear horn sits in a stone rocking chair next to a pile of iron molds and clamps.
{@b Iron Bars}. The south half of the room contains four uneven stacks of iron bars, each stack nearly filling a 6-foot cube.

Old age has rendered the duergar smith, Ghorso, deaf and nearly immobile. His walking speed is 10 feet with the cane or 5 feet without it. Despite his age, he is fully armed and armored. He would rather die in combat than succumb to the ravages of age, but he fights only in self-defense. If the characters try to talk to him, he plays dumb and is not the least bit helpful. A {@spell lesser restoration} spell or similar magic can restore Ghorso's hearing, for which he is not the least bit grateful. "Now I can hear every wretched noise in this gods-forsaken place!" he says with a sneer.

Clamped iron molds from {@area areas 16a|a57|x} and {@area 16b|a59} are brought here to cool. Once they reach room temperature (50 degrees Fahrenheit), Ghorso unclamps the molds, opens them, pries out the hardened iron ingots, and stacks them atop the existing piles. It's a tedious, thankless job.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Stockpiled here are 12,800 iron bars, each worth 1 gp and weighing 10 pounds.

entries.name: 16d. Barracks
entries: This room contains two dozen iron cots arranged haphazardly in the middle of the space. Ten {@creature duergar}, five males and five females, are asleep here at any given time, snoring loudly. The males are named Bulborm, Daarsh, Krod, Mranhaim, and Muzdrok. The females are named Azgra, Narlith, Roxinda, Sorka, and Svilla.

The duergar sleep in their armor and keep their weapons within reach. They awaken to sounds of combat in {@area areas 16a|a57|x} or {@area 16b|a59}. A creature that succeeds on a DC 10 Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check can sneak about the room without waking the duergar.

entries.name: 17. Hammers and Anvils
entries: This part of the dungeon rings with the sound of hammers on anvils. As one approaches the forges ({@area areas 17c|a61|x} and {@area 17d|a64}), the sound grows louder and is joined by the roaring and crackling of flames. The light of the forges spills out into the main hallway and, when the door is open, into {@area area 17e|a65|x}.

The duergar guards stationed in these areas have orders to escort visitors to {@creature Valtagar Steelshadow|WDMM} in {@area area 15|a4f|x}. If combat erupts in one room, the occupants of the other rooms join the fight. The duergar in {@area areas 6a|a39|x}, {@area 6b|a3a}, and {@area 6c|a3b} hear echoes of the commotion and investigate, moving 50 feet per round. The inhabitants of other nearby areas go about their business.
The stone floors and walls are covered with bloody tiles. The ceiling is 10 feet high throughout.

entries.name: 17a. Western Guard Post
entries: Two male {@creature duergar}, Kalrog and Klang, keep guard here. Klang is Kalrog's older brother, and the two are highly competitive.

entries.name: 17b. Eastern Guard Post
entries: Smoke and heat from the forges billow into this chamber, keeping it a sweltering 90 degrees Fahrenheit. Two {@creature duergar}—a male named Prax and a female named Torga—mind this watch post, incidentally standing guard over a variety of extra supplies that are stored here. Driven into the south wall are twelve stone pegs on which soot-stained leather aprons and tinted goggles are hung.

entries.name: 17c. Western Smithy

entries: {@b Smoke and Heat}. Smoke fills this room, rendering everything in the area lightly obscured. The temperature here is a scorching 120 degrees Fahrenheit.
{@b Forge}. Crackling flames fill a stone forge that protrudes from the north wall. An iron anvil squats in front of the forge (which is similar to the one in {@area area 16a|a57|x}).

{@b Smiths}. Two sweaty, female {@creature duergar} are fashioning an iron javelin. Both are unarmored, wearing leather aprons and gloves. One of them wears tinted iron goggles as she hammers the javelin into shape. The other has an iron eye patch and uses tongs to hold the metal in place as it's struck.
{@b Iron}. The floor is covered with small stacks of iron bars and loose piles of scrap iron.
The duergar, Falthra and Helgra, craft weapons here. Years ago, a flying piece of molten iron put out Helgra's right eye; an iron eye patch bolted to her skull covers the empty eye socket.

Without their armor, Falthra and Helgra have AC 10. They keep their war picks and javelins close by, but fight only in self-defense. Visitors who trouble them are told to seek out Rojkarn Ironhead, the captain of the guard. "He wears a big helmet," one says with a sneer. The other can provide directions to {@area area 6c|a3b|x}, where Rojkarn's office is located.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Sixty iron bars are stacked on the floor. Each bar is worth 1 gp and weighs 10 pounds.

entries.name: 17d. Eastern Smithy
entries: This room is identical to {@area area 17c|a61|x} except that the two unarmored {@creature duergar} working here are males named Forn and Wulluk, and they're fashioning shields and bits of scale mail instead of weapons. Forn is fat and lazy, Wulluk old and cantankerous. They grate on each other's nerves and constantly put each other down. They otherwise behave similarly to the duergar in {@area area 17c|a61|x}.

entries.name: 17e. Armory
entries: Stone pegs in the walls display six dwarf-sized suits of scale mail, ten helmets, ten shields, thirteen war picks, and thirty javelins, all fashioned from iron.

entries.name: 17f. Equipment Storage
entries: The walls of this 10-foot-high room are lined with low stone shelves that hold worn mining picks and hammers. Rusty iron buckets, helmets, and shovels hang from stone pegs above the shelves.

entries.name: 18. Iron Mine
entries: The duergar mine these tunnels for iron ore, which is taken to {@area areas 16a|a57|x} and {@area 16b|a59} to be smelted. The operation runs smoothly because of the merciless oversight of {@creature Stalagma Steelshadow|WDMM}, Valtagar's wife.
The area is filled with the sounds of hammers and picks striking stone. The ceiling is roughly 10 feet high throughout.

entries.name: 18a. Old Scaffolding
entries: A mine track passes through this cave, which is filled with torn-down iron scaffolding. Duergar miners can be heard to the west ({@area area 18b|a69|x}) and the south ({@area areas 18c|a6a|x} and {@area 18d|a6b}).

entries.name: 18b. Duergar Miners
entries: Seven {@creature duergar}—three males named Greorx, Hwahl, and Uzwurn, and four females named Awmok, Nezza, Proxna, and Warda—mine iron ore here. Eager for any distraction, the miners attack intruders on sight. Given the noise that echoes throughout the tunnels, the sound of clashing steel is unlikely to be noticed by the duergar in {@area areas 18c|a6a|x} and {@area 18d|a6b}. Magical explosions or other unusual sounds do draw their attention, though.

entries.name: 18c. A Miner Disturbance
entries: Eleven {@creature duergar} work here. Three of the workers are enlarged female duergar (Brakka, Korla, and Zagra) who use picks to break up a vein of iron ore that runs through the ceiling. Six normal-sized males (Hax, Mruuzdain, Oznur, Ramdrax, Tarnvur, and Yarox) work on expanding the cavern northward, while two normal-sized females (Nura and Speleosa) use hammers and spikes to separate iron from loose chunks of rock. If the miners notice the party, they attack, letting their enlarged allies barrel in first.

entries.name: 18d. Overseer
entries: This section of the mine has been depleted of mithral and iron ore. It contains the following:

{@b Stalagma}. {@creature Stalagma Steelshadow|WDMM}, a female adult steel dragon in duergar form, is mounted on a {@creature gorgon} near the bend in the mine track. (If {@creature Valtagar Steelshadow|WDMM} escaped from {@area area 15|a4f|x}, he is riding behind Stalagma on the gorgon.)
{@b Xorn}. Three {@creature xorn} under Stalagma's command are gathered around a broken mine cart filled with coins.

{@creature Stalagma Steelshadow|wdmm|Stalagma} is {@creature Valtagar Steelshadow|wdmm}'s beloved mate, and only Valtagar knows that his wife is a dragon in disguise. In her true form, Stalagma looks like a slender, 30-foot-long dragon with shiny steel-gray scales covering her body, steely talons, and blade-like horns that sweep back from her narrow head. She has the statistics of an {@creature adult silver dragon}, with these changes:

items: Stalagma is lawful evil.

While in duergar form, she has the Duergar Resilience and Sunlight Sensitivity traits of a {@creature duergar}, as well as its Enlarge and Invisibility action options. In this form, she wields a glaive and can use her action to attack with it three times (+13 to hit), dealing 13 ({@dice 1d10 + 8}) slashing damage on a hit, or 19 ({@dice 2d10 + 8}) slashing damage in her enlarged duergar form.
Instead of Cold Breath, she breathes acid in a 60-foot-long, 5-foot-wide line. The breath weapon deals acid damage instead of cold damage.
She speaks Draconic, Dwarvish, and Terran.

entries: Stalagma is as miserable and conniving as any duergar. She raised the gorgon, and it allows no one except her to ride it. The beast is smart enough to obey Stalagma's verbal commands, and it's strong enough to bear her weight while she's in her enlarged duergar form.

Stalagma attacks any non-duergar who aren't under her husband's protection. If additional reinforcements are needed, Stalagma bellows, "To arms!" in Dwarvish. Her booming voice causes the duergar in {@area areas 18b|a69|x} and {@area 18c|a6a} to stop working and converge on her location with their weapons drawn. The battle cry also awakens the guards sleeping in {@area area 19b|a73|x}, who collect their weapons and investigate. If her gorgon mount is killed or she is taking too much damage as a duergar, Stalagma uses her next action to revert to her true form. Other duergar who see Stalagma in her true form flee unless Valtagar is present to reassure them that the dragon is their ally.
Stalagma controls the xorn by feeding them treasure from the broken-down mine cart. In addition to Dwarvish and Draconic, she speaks Terran, so the xorn can understand her.

entries.name: Xorn
entries: The xorn are initially hostile toward Stalagma's enemies. They quickly become indifferent toward characters who offer them gems as food, preferring such delicacies to the coins that Stalagma usually feeds them.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The mine cart has two broken axles. It contains 2,000 sp and 3,200 gp.

entries.name: 19. Outpost
entries: These chambers guard the stairs to {@adventure level 22|WDMM|22}. The ceilings are 20 feet high throughout.

entries.name: 19a. Way to Level 22

entries: {@b Debris}. In the west side of the room lie the crumbling remains of a stone table and four stone stools.

{@b Pillars}. Three stone pillars in the east side of the room are streaked with glittering mithral veins that look like lightning bolts shooting up from the floor. (Any attempt to extract the mithral from the pillars proves futile.)

{@b Xindulus}. An {@condition invisible} {@creature ultroloth} named Xindulus guards a secret door leading to a 10-foot-wide spiral staircase that descends to {@adventure level 22|WDMM|22} (see "Secret Door" below).

If anyone opens the secret door, the ultroloth appears and tries to slay them. It ignores those who leave the secret door alone, allowing them to move through the area unmolested. If threatened by three or more enemies, it tries to summon {@dice 1d6} {@creature Mezzoloth||mezzoloths}, {@dice 1d4} {@creature Nycaloth||nycaloths}, or another {@creature ultroloth} (see the "Variant: Yugoloth Summoning" sidebar in the "Yugoloths" entry in the {@book Monster Manual|MM}).
Xindulus won't negotiate with adventurers unless they offer it something immensely valuable, such as a legendary magic item or an artifact.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: A fresco that depicts dwarves battling a black pudding conceals the secret door in the north wall. Bloodstains mar the carving, making the dwarves look horribly wounded and giving the ooze a disgustingly realistic sheen. The secret door stands in a section of wall that bears the image of a dwarf wizard wielding a staff. The staff is made of real iron and is partially embedded in the stone.

An {@spell arcane lock} has been cast on the secret door. A {@spell knock} spell causes the door to swing inward, revealing a dusty tunnel that ends at a downward-spiraling staircase. Forcing open the magically locked door requires a successful DC 25 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. Touching an iron object to the iron staff in the fresco suppresses the {@spell arcane lock} spell for 1 minute.

entries.name: 19b. Empty Barracks
entries: This room is empty.

entries.name: 20. Poisonous Mine
entries: These chambers have 15-foot-high ceilings, with 10-foot-high tunnels connecting them. The sounds of picks striking stone echo throughout, becoming louder as one approaches {@area areas 20b|a76|x} and {@area 20c|a77}.

Noxious gas seeps into this mine through small fissures in the walls, filling areas east of the door to {@area area 19a|a7a|x} and south of the door at {@area area 20d|a78|x}, except for {@area area 21|a79|x}. The gas is invisible, but characters can smell the toxic fumes and hear a faint hissing. It takes 1 minute for the gas to build up in a creature's system, after which the creature must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned}. A creature that holds its breath for the whole minute has advantage on the saving throw, while a creature that doesn't need to breathe automatically succeeds. A creature can end the gas's effect on itself by finishing a short rest in a location with clean air. A {@spell lesser restoration} spell or similar magic also ends the effect on a creature.

entries.name: 20a. Halaster's Watching!
entries: The characters encounter one of Halaster's scrying eyes (see "{@area Halaster's Lair|bb9|x}") in this otherwise empty cave. The scrying sensor watches them until they leave, then disappears.

entries.name: 20b. Poisoned Miners
entries: Three {@condition poisoned} {@creature duergar} (two males and one female) use picks to chip iron ore from the walls of this cave. If outnumbered, they turn {@condition invisible} and join their fellows in {@area area 20c|a77|x}. Otherwise, they attack. The males are named Orn and Thumrok. The female is named Durundra.

entries.name: 20c. Poisoned Miners
entries: Eight {@condition poisoned} {@creature duergar} (six males and two females) lethargically swing their picks, working iron veins in the cavern walls. They are hostile toward non-duergar. They're bold if they outnumber their foes but flee to {@area area 21|a79|x} if that situation changes. The males are named Hrok, Jarazk, Krod, Mraginar, Norl, and Rok. The females are named Bralith and Sunmerva.

The cave is strewn with old mining equipment: shovels, broken picks, rusty iron sleds for dragging ore, and so forth. A casual search also yields a pair of empty water skins, a shattered wooden ale cask, and a 20-foot-long coil of hempen rope too old to be of much use.

entries.name: 20d. Empty Room
entries: Dwarves dug through the south wall of this room, hoping to find rich veins of mithral. Instead, they found iron and poisonous gas. The room is empty, though characters can hear the miners working in {@area areas 20b|a76|x} and {@area 20c|a77}.

entries.name: 21. Clean Air Station
entries: The duergar come here to shake off the effects of the poison gas. Runes are chiseled into the smooth gray walls. A character who studies the runes and succeeds on a DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check realizes they are part of an ancient spell that continually and perpetually freshens the air in this room while hedging out poisonous gases and similar effects, magical or otherwise.
{@b Walls}. Interlocking stone tiles cover the floor and walls of this 10-foot-high room.

{@b Portcullis}. An iron portcullis blocks the tunnel to the south. The portcullis can be forcibly lifted by creatures who have a combined Strength of 50 or higher. The bars of the portcullis are spaced 3 inches apart.
{@b Lever}. A stone lever in the down position juts from the angled wall east of the portcullis. (Moving this lever to the up position raises the portcullis.)

entries.name: 23. Fazrian's Court
entries: Time and neglect have diminished the grandeur of these vaulted halls, wherein the fallen angel awaits.

entries.name: 23a. Grand Foyer
entries: The 18-foot-high double doors to the west swing inward, revealing a stone-tiled foyer with a 40-foot-high ceiling. The area contains the following features:
{@b Braziers}. The foyer is heated and dimly lit by two 6-foot-tall, 6-foot-wide stone braziers filled with burning coals. Smoke and embers rise from each.

{@b Statues}. Extending eastward from the foyer is a 20-foot-wide, 30-foot-high arched hall lined with 15-foot-tall iron statues of armored dwarves draped in cobwebs. {@spell Continual flame} spells flicker behind the eye holes of their helms, and their iron greataxes are raised high.

entries.name: 23b. Hall of Final Judgment
entries: The floor of this 40-foot-high chamber is shaped like the head of a double-bladed axe. The room, which smells of roses and sulfur, contains the following:

{@b Fazrian and Fiend}. A hairless, green-skinned planetar with white-feathered wings and eyes of molten silver sits on a bone throne in a raised alcove. Lurking in the shadows behind the throne is Raxxus, a {@creature nycaloth}. (The yugoloth passively guards the wall behind it, which contains a secret door to {@area area 24|a85|x}.)
{@b Braziers}. The chamber is dimly lit by four 6-foot-tall, 6-foot-wide stone braziers filled with burning coals that produce smoke and embers.
{@b Standing Gate}. To the north stands a pair of crystal menhirs, each imprisoning a {@creature marilith}.

{@b Open Pit}. A gaping pit lies to the south, its rectangular mouth measuring 10 feet wide by 20 feet long by 30 feet deep, with a 20-foot-high, 20-foot-wide passage at the bottom leading south. Characters near the lip of the pit can hear large creatures (the otyughs in {@area area 23c|a83|x}) shuffling in the darkness below.

{@creature Fazrian|WDMM} is a lawful evil {@creature planetar} that lacks the Healing Touch action option. Unless he is {@condition incapacitated}, {@creature Fazrian|WDMM} can take one of the following lair actions on initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties) while on the Terminus Level:

items: Blood flows from {@creature Fazrian|WDMM}'s eyes until initiative count 20 on the next round. No creature within 120 feet of the planetar can regain hit points until the effect ends.

{@creature Fazrian|WDMM}'s eyes become smoldering black voids until initiative count 20 on the next round. All other creatures within 120 feet of the planetar have disadvantage on saving throws until the effect ends.

Blinding magical light springs from {@creature Fazrian|WDMM}'s eyes until initiative count 20 on the next round. If a creature starts its turn within 120 feet of the planetar and the two of them can see each other, {@creature Fazrian|WDMM} can force the creature to make a DC 20 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is {@condition blinded}. The blindness lasts until the creature receives a {@spell lesser restoration} spell or similar magic.

entries: Once an exemplar of courage and good judgment, {@creature Fazrian|WDMM} now seeks to destroy any creature it believes is undeserving of continued existence. {@creature Fazrian|WDMM}'s views are a mockery of what they once were. Every creature is guilty of "deformity" in the planetar's eyes. Unless someone can swiftly prove their innocence, {@creature Fazrian|WDMM} sentences that individual to an immediate death.

Persuading the planetar to render a verdict of not guilty requires at least one party member to submit to {@creature Fazrian|WDMM}'s judgment. That character must then offer to surrender their own life to spare the lives of the others. Any character who stands before {@creature Fazrian|WDMM} and shows both courage and self-sacrifice is found innocent of the crime of deformity. Denials, protests, and challenges to {@creature Fazrian|WDMM}'s authority are met with stern pronouncements of guilt. The planetar can tell when it is being lied to (thanks to its Divine Awareness trait), and characters who lie to {@creature Fazrian|WDMM} are immediately judged guilty.

The planetar has delusions of raising an army to sweep through Undermountain and purge it of those it deems abhorrent. Before letting innocents off the hook, {@creature Fazrian|WDMM} demands that they each swear an oath to serve it henceforth. Those who refuse to take the oath are found guilty of the crime of cowardice and sentenced to death.

Once judgment is rendered, {@creature Fazrian|WDMM} orders Raxxus to step forth, slay the guilty party or parties, and cast their bodies into the pit (see {@area area 23c|a83|x}). After the guilty have been punished, those found innocent are escorted by Raxxus to the arcanaloths in {@area area 14|a4c|x} for indoctrination. If the nycaloth is killed, the planetar takes up its sword and attacks the guilty.

Only a character judged innocent by {@creature Fazrian|WDMM} can alter the planetar's disposition enough to make it realize how corrupt it has become. Such a character can use an action to call on the planetar to look inward and judge itself, making a DC 26 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check as part of that action. If the player roleplays well, grant the character advantage on the check. A character who gets a failure on the check can't try again, but they can still help another character who then tries to convince the planetar of its own guilt. On a successful check of this sort, a lingering shred of goodness in {@creature Fazrian|WDMM} is awakened. The planetar weeps as it begs Torm for forgiveness. Then, in a final act of atonement and self-sacrifice, it impales itself on its sword and dies.

If the planetar dies by its own hand or at the hands of the characters, Torm bestows on each character a {@i blessing of protection} (see "{@book Supernatural Gifts|DMG|8|Supernatural Gifts}" in chapter 7 of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}). This blessing is permanent if its receiver is a worshiper of Torm; otherwise, the blessing lasts for 10 days. Torm's blessing is not bestowed on any character who releases one or both mariliths that are trapped in the crystal menhirs (see "Standing Gate to Level 19" below).

entries.name: Nycaloth
entries: Raxxus serves as the planetar's executioner, ready to step forward and slay whatever {@creature Fazrian|WDMM} commands it to kill. Raxxus can summon other yugoloths (as described in the "Variant: Yugoloth Summoning" sidebar in the "Yugoloths" entry in the {@book Monster Manual|MM}) and tries to do so if reinforcements are needed. Characters who defeat the planetar can tempt Raxxus with a bribe. Treasure in the amount of 10,000 gp or more can change the nycaloth's attitude toward the party from hostile to indifferent; treasure in the amount of 25,000 gp or more changes its attitude to friendly. Raxxus won't hurt the characters if it's indifferent toward them and helps the characters if it's friendly toward them. The nycaloth's disposition reverts to hostile if the characters threaten it or fail to make payment in a reasonable amount of time.

entries.name: Standing Gate to Level 19
entries: The crystal menhirs are indestructible and form one of Halaster's magic gates (see "{@area Gates|028|x}"). Striking either menhir with a hard object or targeting one or both with a {@spell shatter} spell deals no damage, but causes an affected standing stone to emit a loud ringing that awakens the marilith demon inside. Nothing else causes these demons to awaken.

The first thing an awakened marilith does is free itself using its Teleport action option. The mariliths are hostile toward all creatures that aren't demons, and they despise angels most of all. If a marilith is released in {@creature Fazrian|WDMM}'s presence, the demon and the angel fight until only one is left standing. If the planetar is forced to fight one marilith by itself, assume that {@creature Fazrian|WDMM} emerges victorious with 60 hit points remaining. If forced to fight both mariliths by itself, {@creature Fazrian|WDMM} is killed and each demon is left with 60 hit points.

After being released from its menhir, a marilith can be magically compelled to divulge the command word that activates the gate. A {@spell legend lore} spell or similar magic also reveals the command word. The current command word is "Yuraj," but Halaster changes it every few days. The rules of this gate are as follows:

items: The gate opens for 1 minute if a creature speaks the proper command word within 10 feet of it.

Los personajes deben ser de nivel 15 o superior para atravesar esta puerta (ver "{@area Jhesiyra Kestellharp|016|x}"). La primera criatura que atraviesa la puerta activa una runa de anciano (ver "{@area Elder Runes|027|x}").
A creature that passes through the gate appears in {@area area 7 on level 19|990|x}, in the closest unoccupied space next to the similar gate located there.

entries.name: 23c. Garbage Disposal
entries: A 20-foot-wide, 20-foot-high tunnel at the bottom of the pit in {@area area 23b|a7f|x} leads south before coming to a dead end. The floor of the tunnel is covered with bones, bits of adventuring gear, and other debris.
At the end of the tunnel lurk three hungry {@creature Otyugh||otyughs}. When they detect other creatures in the pit, they rush forth and attack while using their Limited Telepathy to taunt prey.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Scattered among the bones at the south end of the tunnel are 1,300 sp, 600 gp, and a thin gold playing card stamped with the image of a masked man and titled "The Thief." The card is worth 10 gp and completes a deck of cards found in {@area area 10b|a42|x}.

entries.name: 24. Secret Vault
entries: This oval chamber has a domed ceiling 20 feet high, as well as the following features:
{@b Bloody Hand}. Dry blood stains every surface except for a patch in the shape of a giant hand on the back wall.

{@b Head and Mace}. Piled in the middle of the room are ten shattered stone chests. A mace and a headless human corpse lie on the floor next to this rubble. The corpse's severed head lies a few feet away. Maggots feast on the rotting remains.
Any character who succeeds on a DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check realizes that the hand shape on the back wall resembles the symbol of Torm.

Characters who witnessed the ghostly scene in {@area area 7|a3c|x} recognize the corpse as that of the cleric in the vision. Brythia Mulspeer and her adventuring companions were exploring Undermountain when the perils became too much for them. Brythia petitioned Torm for aid, and {@creature Fazrian|WDMM} answered the summons. The planetar provided much-needed assistance and healing, then chose to remain by Brythia's side as the adventurers descended deeper into Undermountain. When blood lust finally took hold of the planetar, it turned on the adventurers and decapitated Brythia with its greatsword. This former cleric of Torm can be questioned using {@spell speak with dead}. Having succumbed to {@creature Fazrian|WDMM}'s blood lust, Brythia wishes only to see the planetar redeemed.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The mace is a {@item mace of smiting} that belonged to Brythia. Characters who witnessed the ghostly scene in area 7 recognize the mace as the weapon used by the cleric in that vision.
The stone chests once contained coins hidden here by Melairkyn dwarves. The duergar broke open the chests and dumped the coins in a mining cart in {@area area 18d|a6b|x}.

entries.name: Aftermath
entries: {@creature Fazrian|WDMM}'s death enables the duergar to regain control of the Terminus Level. Valtagar has no immediate plans other than to fortify the level and prepare for his eventual return to Gracklstugh.

Any yugoloths that remain make the best of a bad situation. Aximus and Exekarus are more likely to ally with the duergar than with a band of adventurers, while Raxxus prefers to accompany the adventurers rather than stay with the duergar. If Xindulus is alive, the ultroloth takes its chances in Shadowdusk Hold ({@adventure level 22|WDMM|22}), trying to forge an alliance with the death knights there.

Regardless of what happens, the Mad Mage continues to use the Terminus Level as a dumping ground for failed monster experiments. Characters who leave the level and later return might encounter one or more of these horrors.

data.name: Level 22: Shadowdusk Hold
entries: Shadowdusk Hold is designed for four 17th-level characters, and characters who defeat the monsters on this level should gain enough XP to advance halfway to 18th level.

entries.name: What Dwells Here?
entries: A Waterdavian noble family driven into exile long ago has carved out a home for itself on this level.

entries.name: The Shadowdusks
entries: The Shadowdusk family, like many other Waterdavian noble lineages, made its fortune in trading. Three sisters named Arandraya, Maelweene, and Yarlithra Shadowdusk became famous for sponsoring and then leading adventuring expeditions into Undermountain. One of the items they recovered from the dungeon was a tablet of black crystal that allowed contact with entities of the Far Realm. Their brother, Xerrion, came to possess the tablet and used it to contact otherworldly beings in an attempt to destroy his family's business rivals and political enemies. This contact drove Xerrion mad, and it didn't take long for the madness to spread to other members of the Shadowdusk family and come into public view. As the family's behavior grew more bizarre, local broadsheets circulated rumors that the Shadowdusks had been replaced by aberrant horrors in human guise. Their ancestral villa, Shadowdusk Hold, was burned to the ground in the Year of the Harp (1355 DR). The Waterdavian authorities who investigated the blaze never made their findings public, but the commonly held belief is that the city's Watchful Order of Magists and Protectors was responsible.

All three of Xerrion's sisters were killed in the fire that consumed Shadowdusk Hold. Xerrion escaped and fled to his sisters' redoubt in the depths of Undermountain. From there, he used {@spell sending} spells to contact Shadowdusk family members living abroad and brought them to live with him in a twisted, underground version of Shadowdusk Hold. Among those who answered the call was Margaraste Shadowdusk, a distant cousin whom Xerrion would later marry.

Level 22 of Undermountain became a safe haven where the Shadowdusks could treat with Far Realm horrors away from the prying eyes of their fellow Waterdavians. In the end, Xerrion and Margaraste stepped through a gateway into the Far Realm and were never seen again. In their absence, the torch of leadership passed to Xerrion's niece and nephew, Dezmyr and Zalthar—the twin children of his late sister Yarlithra. These former paladins of Torm abandoned their faith long ago, becoming death knights.

Over the years, {@creature Halaster Blackcloak|WDMM} has kept his eye on the Shadowdusks and their plots, even as he allows the family free rein in their corner of his domain. The Mad Mage has decided that these are the kinds of nobles that need to be making decisions and wielding power in Waterdeep—so that he can secretly rule the city using them as puppets. As such, he encourages the Shadowdusks to consolidate power in preparation for a triumphant and bloody return to Waterdeep, after which Halaster will seize power as the city's Shadow Lord.

The Shadowdusk family motto used to be "No secrets without truth." After the family's fall, its motto changed to "We do not fear the darkness." The family's crest is a lit torch with three embers rising from the flame, set against a purple background. In the wake of the family's descent into Undermountain and madness, this crest has been literally turned upside down, so that the torch flame points downward.

entries.name: Star Spawn
entries: Creatures from the Far Realm visit Shadowdusk Hold from time to time. If you have a copy of {@book Mordenkainen's Tome of Foes|MTF}, you can add one or more star spawn from that book to the roster of creatures encountered on this level of Undermountain.

entries.name: Dezmyr and Zalthar
entries: The current leaders of Shadowdusk Hold are the twins {@creature Dezmyr Shadowdusk|wdmm|Dezmyr} and {@creature Zalthar Shadowdusk|wdmm}. They have remained close throughout life and undeath, and might have led their mortal family skillfully if circumstances had played out differently.
The twins are devoted to each other and are obsessed with returning their family to prominence and ultimately seizing control of Waterdeep.

entries.name: Exploring This Level
entries: All location descriptions for this level are keyed to map 22.
The following features apply throughout Shadowdusk Hold unless otherwise noted in an area's description:

items: The hold consists of three tiers. Ceilings in rooms and hallways are 15 feet high unless stated otherwise. The floors are smooth stone polished to a mirror finish.

Any humanoid that dies in Shadowdusk Hold rises from its corpse {@dice 1d4} hours later as a {@creature will-o'-wisp} under the DM's control. Casting {@spell dispel evil and good} on the corpse before the will-o'-wisp forms prevents such an occurrence, as does bringing the body out of Shadowdusk Hold or into the area of a {@spell hallow} spell.
Sconces throughout Shadowdusk Hold flicker with torchlight created by {@spell continual flame} spells. These magic torches are set in upside-down sconces, and their magical flames point downward.

entries.name: Tier 1
entries: The uppermost tier of Shadowdusk Hold closely resembles the style and architecture of the family manor in Waterdeep before it was destroyed. This section of the hold resembles a mausoleum. The Far Realm's influence on this tier is faint.
Two members of the Shadowdusk family reside here: a wizard named {@creature Melissara Shadowdusk|WDMM} and her mad husband, Derrion.

entries.name: 1. Grand Foyer
entries: The stairs from {@adventure level 21|WDMM|21} descend to a grand entry chamber that contains the following features:
{@b Pillars}. Pillars support the 40-foot-high, vaulted ceiling.
{@b Grells}. Six {@creature Grell||grells} float behind the pillars to the north. The grells attack visitors and can use their tentacles to open and close doors as needed.

{@b Apparitions}. Spectral images of dead servants and adventurers occasionally fade into view, wander the hall, then fade away. These images are harmless regional effects created by Halaster (see "{@area Halaster's Lair|bb9|x}").
{@b Statues}. Statues depicting two well-dressed humans stand in alcoves to the south.

The statues show the Shadowdusk twins, Zalthar and Dezmyr, as they appeared in life. Zalthar's statue is in the west alcove and stands 6 feet 11 inches tall. Dezmyr's statue to the east stands 6 feet 3 inches tall. An inscription on the bottom of each statue identifies its subject.

entries.name: 2. Twisted Gallery

entries: {@b Bas-Reliefs}. The curved walls are lined with bas-relief carvings, and plaques mounted beneath them tell the story of a forgotten Waterdavian family.
{@b Statues}. Two 9-foot-tall statues stand on raised platforms in alcoves to the north and south.

The bas-reliefs carvings depict Arandraya, Maelweene, and Yarlithra Shadowdusk negotiating trade deals in Waterdeep, exploring Undermountain in their free time, pouring treasure into family coffers, and giving a black tablet to their brother, Xerrion. The carvings go on to show the original Shadowdusk Hold (in Waterdeep) on fire, Xerrion Shadowdusk escaping into Undermountain with the black tablet, the creation of a new Shadowdusk Hold in the dungeon's depths, Xerrion's marriage to Lady Margaraste, and the married couple stepping through a gate of tentacles into the Far Realm.

A successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill History}) check identifies the family crest in the reliefs—a lit torch with an orange flame and three embers trailing off it—and the two mottoes of House Shadowdusk: "No secrets without truth" and "We do not fear the darkness." The crest appears upright in earlier scenes and inverted in later scenes. A character who recognizes the crest and the family mottoes also knows that the Shadowdusks were presumed destroyed.

The statue to the north depicts Lord Xerrion Shadowdusk, a male human of middle age with regal bearing and sharp features. The south statue depicts Lady Margaraste Shadowdusk, a middle-aged female human with long, curly hair and a kind smile. An inscription on the bottom of each statue identifies its subject.

entries.name: 3. West Wing
entries: Four {@creature Nothic||nothics} lurk in the northern arm of this L-shaped gallery, poring over wall carvings and chattering to themselves. Beyond the nothics, a staircase descends 50 feet to {@area tier 2|a92|x}.
The nothics are puzzled by the carvings, which depict various deceased members of the Shadowdusk family. They attack intruders on sight.

entries.name: 4. Decayed Quarters
entries: This suite of chambers has been destroyed by the creatures now in residence here, all traces of the rooms' previous purposes obliterated.

entries.name: 4a. Grell Nest
entries: A hive-like nest with multiple dark openings fills the southern half of this room. Seven {@creature Grell||grells} lurk inside the wet, papery nest and emerge from it to attack intruders.

entries.name: 4b. Mad Creature

entries: {@b Nothic}. A {@creature nothic} squats near the east wall, frantically scratching at the stone.
{@b Scrawls}. Scrawled exhortations in Deep Speech and Undercommon cover the walls, floor, and ceiling.

The nothic used to be an apprentice mage named Rhamagant, who served as {@creature Vertrand Shadowdusk|WDMM}'s assistant (see {@area area 17|ac1|x} for more information about Vertrand). The nothic remembers nothing of its previous life and fights only in self-defense. A character who questions the nothic in a language it understands can glean the following useful information amid its mad ravings:

items: This level of Undermountain is called Shadowdusk Hold, and it has three tiers.
The deeper into Shadowdusk Hold one goes, the closer one gets to the Far Realm.
There's a secret room on each tier.

entries: The nothic knows the locations of all the secret doors leading to the secret rooms in Shadowdusk Hold (areas {@area 11|aaa}, {@area 23b|ad7}, and {@area 37|afe}). Any character who can communicate with the nothic can, with a successful DC 20 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation} or {@skill Persuasion}) check, convince it to accompany the party and point out secret doors. When it comes within 10 feet of a secret door in Shadowdusk Hold, the nothic begins scratching at it while muttering the words "secret door" in Undercommon.
{@b Cold}. This chamber is kept magically cold.
{@b Shelves}. Shelves line every wall, all of them stacked with wine, ale, and perishable food.
{@b Casks}. Several wooden casks of drinkable water stand along one wall.
{@b Furnishings}. This room contains an iron stove, three wooden tables for preparing food, and a cupboard holding silver utensils and dishware.
{@b Unseen Servants}. Four {@creature Living Unseen Servant|WDMM|living unseen servants} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}) prepare meals on command and use brooms to sweep the floor.

entries.name: 7. Derelict Shrine
entries: An incomplete statue partially hewn from marble stands in the middle of the area. The stone is carved into the rough shape of the god Torm. Someone who succeeds on a DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check identifies the statue's unfinished features as the iconography of the god of duty, loyalty, and law.

entries.name: 8. Nothic's Niche

entries: {@b Fissure}. A {@creature nothic} hides in a 5-foot-wide natural fissure in the 20-foot-high ceiling.
{@b Furnishings}. A rectangular stone table with ten chairs stands at the center of the room. The table and the floor around it are strewn with debris from the crumbling ceiling.
{@b Tapestry}. A great tapestry covers the west wall. It depicts a noble wedding inside a vast chamber that has shadowy tentacles sprouting from its dark corners.

The nothic uses the fissure in the ceiling as a private lair. It observes intruders and uses its Weird {@skill Insight} on interesting-looking characters so it can later report any secrets it learns to {@creature Dezmyr Shadowdusk|WDMM}. It leaves the niche only if attacked and fights to the death to defend its lair.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Stashed on a shelf inside the nothic's ceiling niche are 15 pp and 200 gp in a leather sack, and a {@item potion of supreme healing} in a glass vial fastened to a silver necklace (25 gp).
The tapestry depicts the ghastly wedding of Xerrion and Margaraste Shadowdusk. It is worth 750 gp and weighs 50 pounds.

entries.name: 9. East Wing

entries: {@b Drifting Light}. A visible {@creature will-o'-wisp} drifts through this long, L-shaped gallery.
{@b Carving}. An alcove in the corner of the L bears a relief carving of Shadowdusk nobles being paid respect by the common folk.
{@b Stairs}. A staircase at the end of the north arm of the gallery descends 50 feet to {@area tier 2|a92|x}.

The will-o'-wisp serves Melissara in {@area area 10a|aa4|x}. It wanders from one end of the hall to the other, waiting for her summons, but turns {@condition invisible} and flees to warn her at the first sign of intruders.

entries.name: 10. Noble Quarters
entries: This suite belongs to {@creature Melissara Shadowdusk|WDMM}, a distant cousin of the Shadowdusk twins, and her deranged husband, Derrion.

entries.name: 10a. Melissara's Chamber

entries: {@b Melissara}. A middle-aged woman ({@creature Melissara Shadowdusk|WDMM}) sits in an easy chair in the northeast corner, reading and muttering to herself.
{@b Other Furnishings}. A canopied bed and an armoire stand against the south wall, and a silk curtain obscures a corridor to the north.
{@b Secret Door}. A secret door in the east wall opens into Melissara's study ({@area area 11|aaa|x}).

Melissara has so far managed to escape the horrible insanity that besets the rest of her family, but she can sense that her mind is slowly being eroded by contact with the Far Realm. Fearing that her descent into madness is inevitable, she lives in a state of self-imposed exile and chooses to remain in Shadowdusk Hold despite every instinct telling her to flee.
Melissara is a human {@creature archmage}, with these changes:

items: Melissara is neutral.
She speaks Common, Deep Speech, Draconic, and Dwarvish.
She has the {@spell dimension door} spell prepared instead of {@spell banishment}.

entries: If the characters address her in a civilized manner, Melissara listens to what they have to say. She then implores them to destroy Dezmyr and Zalthar before they can enact their plan to conquer Waterdeep, not realizing that death knights are not so easily vanquished. Melissara asks that she and Derrion be left out of the ensuing conflict and provides the following information to the characters in good faith:

items: All members of the Shadowdusk family have, to some extent, been corrupted by the Far Realm. To the best of Melissara's knowledge, the damage is irreparable.
Other family members living in Shadowdusk Hold include Melissara's three cousins: the wizards Berlain, Cassiok, and Vertrand.

Dezmyr and Zalthar are death knights that dwell on the lower tiers of Shadowdusk Hold. Contact with the Far Realm has given Dezmyr the ability to warp reality to a limited extent. Zalthar has no such ability but wields a sword that drains souls.

The lowest tier of Shadowdusk Hold is home to a blue dracolich in league with the death knights. (Melissara knows the dracolich's phylactery is hidden somewhere in Shadowdusk Hold, but doesn't know where.)

entries: If the characters have no interest in conversing with Melissara, she uses {@spell dimension door} to get to {@area area 11|aaa|x} and sends her lunatic husband to eliminate them.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The armoire holds fine clothing and a wooden jewelry box containing a pair of matching gold bracelets (250 gp each), a gold-and-pearl necklace (1,250 gp), and the key to the strongbox in {@area area 10b|aa7|x}.

entries.name: 10b. Derrion's Chamber

entries: {@b Derrion}. A middle-aged man with a scarred face (Derrion Shadowdusk) is pacing about the room anxiously.
{@b Furnishings}. These include a simple bed to the west, a dresser filled with clothes to the east, and a weapon and armor rack.
Derrion enjoys killing unwelcome visitors. He is a human {@creature champion|VGM} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}), with these changes:

items: Derrion is chaotic evil.
He speaks Common and Deep Speech.
Derrion stores his weapons and plate armor on the equipment racks. If he doesn't have time to don his plate armor, he makes do with a chain shirt (AC 15).

entries: Derrion accompanies Melissara whenever she leaves their suite, fearing that she will come to harm without his protection. He lives in constant fear that adventurers might invade Shadowdusk Hold and lay waste to it. Prolonged exposure to the Far Realm has made him sleep-deprived and irritable. His eyes are bloodshot, and he hears whispers of things that aren't real. Only Melissara can control his inexplicable rage toward visitors.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Under the bed is a locked strongbox containing 200 pp and 1,000 gp. The key in area {@area 10a|aa4} unlocks the strongbox, which can also be opened with a {@spell knock} spell or similar magic, or by a character using thieves' tools who succeeds on a DC 15 Dexterity check.
{@b Bookcase}. A long bookcase with glass doors takes up much of the north wall (see "Bookcase" below).
{@b Desk}. A sturdy writing desk covered in stacks of parchment stands against the east wall (see "Desk" below).
{@b Workbench}. A workbench near the south wall holds a set of alchemist's supplies.

entries.name: Bookcase
entries: The bookcase's glass doors aren't locked.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The case holds texts on various arcane subjects, focusing on evocation magic and planar travel. Three of the texts are valuable (100 gp each). They are titled {@i Tenebrous and the True Path to Lichdom}, {@i Musings of a Planar Traveler}, and {@i Touched by the Far Realm: A Wizard's Lamentable Descent into Lunacy}. Tucked among these mundane tomes is Melissara's spellbook, which bears the (right side up) Shadowdusk family crest on the cover and contains the spells Melissara has prepared, plus {@spell arcane lock} and {@spell glyph of warding}.

entries.name: Desk
entries: The desk holds an orderly stack of notes. Half of the notes detail meticulous magical experiments and studies regarding the nature of the Far Realm. The other notes are nonsensical ravings that hint at a fractured mind slowly coming undone.

The bottom drawer is sealed with an {@spell arcane lock} spell cast by Melissara. Inside is a small black journal. The first page of the book is trapped with a {@spell glyph of warding} spell, whose explosive runes deal fire damage (save DC 15). The glyph is keyed to go off if anyone but Melissara opens the journal (a precaution to prevent her cousins from reading it and discovering her secrets).

The journal details Melissara's unease with her family, as well as her growing fear of losing her mind and soul to the Far Realm. She seems desperate to use her writings in the journal as a touchstone to her own mind.
{@b Tapestry}. A beautiful tapestry covers the west wall (see "Treasure" below).
{@b Furnishings}. Several sitting areas with comfortable chairs and side tables are arranged about the room. An empty bottle of fine wine stands on an end table next to a used wineglass.
{@b Secret Door}. A secret door in the north wall opens into Melissara's study ({@area area 11|aaa|x}).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The tapestry depicts the original Shadowdusk Hold, an impressive villa overgrown with ivy that stood in Waterdeep's Sea Ward until it was burned to the ground. The tapestry is worth 250 gp and weighs 50 pounds.

entries.name: 13. Walking Dead

entries: {@b Zombie}. A human {@creature zombie} in rotting, soiled robes shuffles back and forth through the room. A powerful stench of decay accompanies it.
{@b Furnishings}. Moldy furnishings include a bed, a desk strewn with yellowed papers, and a barren bookshelf.

The zombie is what remains of Zail Ephram, a human wizard and adventurer who was killed in Shadowdusk Hold. {@creature Melissara Shadowdusk|WDMM} ({@area see area 10a|aa4|x}) used an {@spell animate dead} spell to animate the wizard's corpse. The zombie has nothing of value and attacks any creature that disturbs it other than its creator.

The papers on the desk are architectural drawings. Characters who spend 1 hour studying the drawings can piece together accurate maps of tiers 1 and 2 of Shadowdusk Hold, except for secret doors and areas hidden behind them.

entries.name: 14. Training Room

entries: {@b Mannequins}. Two wooden practice dummies stand near the east and west walls.
{@b Racks}. A weapon rack and an armor rack hang on the north wall, one to each side of the doorway.
{@b Mats}. Canvas mats stuffed with straw are spread out to create a sparring area in the middle of the room.

The armor rack contains two shields and two suits each of leather, studded leather, chain shirt, and plate armor. The weapon rack contains one matched pair each of longswords, daggers, battleaxes, quarterstaffs, warhammers, and spears.

entries.name: 15. Fountain
entries: A low-walled marble fountain with a statue of an aboleth as its centerpiece dominates the room. Water spills from the aboleth's mouth and splashes noisily into the stone basin. Drain holes in the basin's rim prevent overflow.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A {@spell detect magic} spell cast on the fountain reveals an aura of conjuration around the aboleth statue, contained within which is the source of the water: a {@item decanter of endless water}. The decanter can be obtained only by destroying the statue, which has AC 17, 60 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage.

entries.name: Tier 2
entries: Stairs from {@area areas 3|a94|x} and {@area 9|aa1} lead down 50 feet to {@area tier 2|a92|x}. Vertrand and Berlain, two thoroughly corrupt and evil members of the Shadowdusk family, inhabit this tier.
Barely perceptible whispers can be heard throughout the tier, and shadowy forms constantly writhe and recoil at the corner of each character's eye.

entries.name: 16. Arcane Sanctum
entries: Three {@condition invisible} {@creature Will-o'-Wisp||will-o'-wisps} linger in this area in case Vertrand or Berlain require their services.

entries.name: 16a. Burned Library
entries: Berlain (see {@area area 18b|ac9|x}) lost her temper here a tenday ago and used multiple {@spell fireball} spells to destroy the room's contents.
{@b Burned Shelves and Racks}. The walls are lined with burned bookshelves and scroll racks.
{@b Charred Furnishings}. The charred remains of three padded chairs and three coffee tables lie atop badly burned rugs in the middle of the floor.

entries.name: 16b. Laboratory
entries: A workbench along the west wall of this area is covered with tools, components, and magical apparatus.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The bench holds a set of {@item alchemist's supplies|PHB}, a {@item poisoner's kit|PHB}, a {@item healer's kit|PHB}, and an unlit lantern filled with oil. A recently brewed {@item potion of invisibility} rests among other vials that contain mundane liquids.

entries.name: 16c. Clean Room

entries: {@b Antimagic}. All magic is suppressed here, as if by an {@spell antimagic field} spell.
{@b Tapestry}. A tapestry on the south wall depicts a landscape of trees made of tentacles, and floating islands of rock covered with drooling mouths and bloodshot eyeballs (see "Treasure" below).

This room is used to rid objects and creatures of undesirable magical energy that might destabilize a sensitive experiment. In addition to the antimagic effect always active in the room, any creature that passes through this area has any magic items it carries and any magical effects active on it suppressed for {@dice 1d4} minutes after it exits. {@spell Detect magic} cast from outside the room does not detect the antimagic field.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The tapestry weighs 30 pounds and is worth 250 gp (assuming the characters can find a buyer who appreciates its disturbing, otherworldly imagery).

entries.name: 17. Vertrand's Room

entries: {@b Vertrand}. A bald, elderly man ({@creature Vertrand Shadowdusk|WDMM}) sits at a writing desk to the north, his back to the doorway.
{@b Bed}. A simple bed stands against the south wall.

{@b Tapestry}. A tapestry hanging on the east wall depicts noble members of the Shadowdusk family, their features distorted in unnatural and frightening ways. (Close examination reveals that the tapestry has been damaged by mold, rendering it worthless.)

Vertrand has smooth flesh where his eyes should be, for he surrendered his ocular orbits to a Far Realm entity in exchange for {@sense blindsight}. Having foreseen the arrival of intruders, Vertrand has elected to face them alone. "Death owns us all," he says, before rising to his feet and unleashing his destructive spells.
Vertrand is a human {@creature archmage}, with these changes:

items: Vertrand is chaotic evil and speaks Abyssal, Common, Deep Speech, and Undercommon.
He has {@sense blindsight} out to a range of 60 feet, but is blind beyond this radius.
He has the {@spell confusion} spell prepared instead of {@spell banishment}.

entries: Vertrand's desk holds writing implements and handwritten notes written by Vertrand before he lost his eyes. The notes are difficult to follow and require a successful DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check to decipher. The notes detail Vertrand's research into magical vortices, and how to widen and destabilize planar portals.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Vertrand's spellbook is in the desk's top drawer. It contains all the spells he has prepared, plus {@spell legend lore}, {@spell conjure elemental}, and {@spell planar binding}. The spells are written out using a form of Braille script.

entries.name: 18. Berlain's Suite
entries: A horribly disfigured mage named {@creature Berlain Shadowdusk|WDMM} claims these chambers.

entries.name: 18a. Study

entries: {@b Furnishings}. A black stone desk stands to the south. Next to the desk is a slender stone lectern with an open book resting on it.
{@b Tapestry}. A tapestry covering the east wall shows a tentacled creature from nightmare stuffing a number of naked, terrified humanoids into its black maw.

Berlain's notes, strewn across her desk, are a blend of arcane esoterica and insane pronouncements. All of it paints a picture of horrific experiments performed on living humanoids. A recently scrawled annotation laments a lack of fresh subjects that is stalling her work.

entries.name: Treasure
